topics.body:
Not to get philosophical here, and I know we're nerding about marvel but I had a interesting thought: everyone knows the phrase "the road to hell is paved with good intentions" on the flip side one can say "the road to good is paved with intentions to help improve others regardless of whether or not one benefits from it regardless of one's internal impulses".

What I mean by this is that there's two kinds of "good" people.  People who genuinely believe in helping others and those that wish to be good.  Call me crazy, but the people who wish to be good are of more value because it takes a deliberate attempt for them to good rather than it coming naturally.

The way I view it is that hypothetically speaking let's say you become the world leader and there's no such thing as resistance against whatever you do: congratulations what is your point?  Everything you could possibly do will be washed away in a generation after your death and nobody will remember you in time.  You could be the world's biggest bastard and declare nuclear war and wipe out all life on earth.  Congratulations; what have you accomplished in the universe?  Why are you important to any extent?

The road to good isn't paved with trying to prove one's self good or even trying to make a difference; rather it's paved with even knowing that no matter what you do you will not be important you do it anyhow.  If you give food to the homeless your act of kindness means nothing on the macro scale, but it's still important cause you did it anyhow.

Essentially: what matters isn't how much you do to help others, rather the fact that you do it in spite of knowing that your act doesn't matter and do it anyhow.

Tl:dr; "good" isn't about trying to make a difference; it's about doing it anyhow.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

It'd be cellphone video of a green wolf in a park doing backflips and stuff then holding a cap for people to put money in and then running off into some alley
